MC: Which of the following processes occurs immediately after ovulation?

column3: a) Certain female hormone levels decrease significantly in quantity.
b) The endometrium sheds its lining and is expelled from the vagina.
c) The inner lining of the uterus thickens in preparation for implantation.
d) Numerous follicles mature and release eggs into the fallopian tubes.

MC
From what internal female organ is the fetus expelled during delivery?

column3: a) Vagina
b) Uterus
c) Cervix
d) Perineum

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1244			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
The vagina and the neck of the uterus comprise the:

column3: a) womb.
b) cervix.
c) fundus.
d) birth canal.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1244			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
The term “bloody show” is defined as:

column3: a) the small amount of pink-tinged mucus that is discharged from the vagina after expulsion of the mucous plug.
b) mild vaginal bleeding that occurs within the first 30 minutes after the onset of the second stage of the labor process.
c) the normal amount of vaginal bleeding that occurs within the first 24 hours following delivery of the baby and placenta.
d) any volume of blood that is expelled from the vagina after the amniotic sac has ruptured and contractions have begun.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1244			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding the placenta is correct?

column3: a) The placenta allows oxygen, carbon dioxide, and other products to transfer between the mother and fetus but does not allow blood to mix between the mother and fetus.
b) The placental barrier consists of two layers of cells and allows the mother’s blood that contains high concentrations of oxygen to directly mix with the blood of the fetus.
c) The placenta, also referred to as the afterbirth, provides oxygen and nutrients to the fetus and is expelled from the vagina about 30 minutes before the baby is born.
d) The placenta allows for the transfer of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the mother and fetus but prevents most medications from passing between the mother and fetus.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1245			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
The umbilical cord:

column3: a) separates from the placenta shortly after birth.
b) carries blood away from the baby via the artery.
c) carries oxygen to the baby via the umbilical vein.
d) contains two veins and one large umbilical artery.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1245			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
The amniotic fluid serves to:

column3: a) transfer oxygen to the fetus.
b) insulate and protect the fetus.
c) remove viruses from the fetus.
d) assist in fetal development.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1245			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
Most medical models base a pregnant woman’s due date:

column3: a) two weeks after her last menstrual cycle.
b) on the last day of her last menstrual cycle.
c) two weeks before her last menstrual cycle.
d) on the first day of her last menstrual cycle.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1246			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Female Reproductive System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-1 Identify the anatomy and physiology of the female reproductive system.
MC
By the 20th week of pregnancy, the uterus is typically at or above the level of the mother’s:

column3: a) belly button.
b) pubic bone.
c) xiphoid process.
d) superior diaphragm.

MC
Which of the following is a normal physiologic change that occurs in the mother’s respiratory system during pregnancy?

column3: a) Decreased respiratory rate and increased minute volume
b) Increased respiratory rate and decreased respiratory reserve
c) Increased respiratory reserve and decreased oxygen demand
d) Increased respiratory depth and decreased respiratory rate

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Normal Changes in Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1246			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Changes in Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-2 Explain the normal changes that occur in the body during pregnancy.
MC
Pregnant women are advised to take iron supplements, such as prenatal vitamins, because:

column3: a) iron makes the blood clot faster, which protects the mother from excessive bleeding during delivery.
b) the blood naturally thins during pregnancy, which predisposes the mother to severe bleeding.
c) white blood cells decrease during pregnancy, which increases the mother’s risk of an infection.
d) pregnancy causes an increased number of red blood cells, which predisposes the mother to anemia.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Normal Changes in Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1246			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Changes in Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-2 Explain the normal changes that occur in the body during pregnancy.
MC
A mother who is pregnant with her first baby is typically in the first stage of labor for approximately:

column3: a) 4 hours.
b) 8 hours.
c) 10 hours.
d) 16 hours.

MC
The onset of labor begins with:

column3: a) thinning of the uterus.
b) full dilation of the cervix.
c) increased fetal movement.
d) contractions of the uterus.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Stages of Labor			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1255			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Stages of Labor			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-8 Differentiate among the three stages of labor.
MC
The term primigravida refers to a woman who:

column3: a) has never been pregnant.
b) has had only one live birth.
c) is pregnant for the first time.
d) has had more than one live baby.

MC
Which of the following occurs during true labor?

column3: a) Uterine contractions decrease in intensity.
b) The uterus becomes very soft and movable.
c) Uterine contractions become more regular.
d) Uterine contractions last about 10 seconds.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Stages of Labor			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1256			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Stages of Labor			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-8 Differentiate among the three stages of labor.
MC
Braxton-Hicks contractions are characterized by:

column3: a) regular contractions of progressively increasing intensity.
b) alleviation of pain with movement or changing positions.
c) pink or red bloody show in conjunction with the contractions.
d) a rupture of the amniotic sac just before the contractions begin.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Stages of Labor			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1256			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Stages of Labor			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-2 Explain the normal changes that occur in the body during pregnancy.
MC
After the fetus has descended into the pelvis at the end of the third trimester, many mothers experience:

column3: a) mid-back pain.
b) a bloated feeling.
c) an urge to push.
d) easier breathing.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Stages of Labor			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1256			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Stages of Labor			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-2 Explain the normal changes that occur in the body during pregnancy.
MC
The third stage of labor begins when the:

column3: a) placenta is fully delivered.
b) cervix is completely dilated.
c) umbilical cord has been clamped.
d) baby is expelled from the vagina.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Stages of Labor			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1256			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Stages of Labor			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-8 Differentiate among the three stages of labor.
MC

A 26-year-old female who is 34 weeks pregnant is experiencing a seizure. Her husband tells you that her blood pressure has been high and that she had been complaining of a headache for the past few days. You should:

column3: a) elevate her legs to improve brain perfusion and keep her warm.
b) administer oral glucose for presumed hypoglycemia and transport.
c) insert an oral airway and ventilate her with a bag-valve mask.
d) place her on her side, administer high-flow oxygen, and transport.

MC
Signs and symptoms of preeclampsia include:

column3: a) headache and edema.
b) marked hypoglycemia.
c) dyspnea and bradycardia.
d) dysuria and constipation.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1248			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
Eclampsia is most accurately defined as:

column3: a) high levels of protein in the patient’s urine.
b) hypertension in the 20th week of pregnancy.
c) seizures that result from severe hypertension.
d) a blood pressure greater than 140/90 mm Hg.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1248			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
Supine hypotensive syndrome occurs when:

column3: a) a supine position kinks the ascending aorta.
b) the pregnant uterus compresses the inferior vena cava.
c) the superior vena cava is compressed by the uterus.
d) blood pressure decreases as a result of hypovolemia.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1248			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
A 33-year-old woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is experiencing vaginal bleeding. During transport, you note that she suddenly becomes diaphoretic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. You should:

column3: a) place her in a left lateral recumbent position.
b) position her supine and elevate her legs 12 inches.
c) carefully place sterile gauze into her vagina.
d) ventilate her with a bag-mask device.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1250			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
The leading cause of maternal death during the first trimester of pregnancy is:

column3: a) massive brain damage secondary to a prolonged seizure.
b) unrecognized or untreated supine hypotensive syndrome.
c) internal bleeding caused by a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
d) blunt trauma to the abdomen during a motor vehicle crash.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1253			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
A history of pelvic inflammatory disease or tubal ligations increases a woman’s risk for:

column3: a) preeclampsia.
b) placenta previa.
c) gestational diabetes.
d) an ectopic pregnancy.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1249			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
Abruptio placenta occurs when:

column3: a) the placenta prematurely separates from the uterine wall.
b) a tear in the placenta causes severe internal hemorrhage.
c) the placenta affixes itself to the outer layer of the uterus.
d) the placenta develops over and covers the cervical opening.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1249			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
Placenta previa is defined as:

column3: a) delivery of a portion of the placenta before the baby.
b) premature placental separation from the uterine wall.
c) abnormal development and functioning of the placenta.
d) development of the placenta over the cervical opening.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1249			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding gestational diabetes is correct?

column3: a) Gestational diabetes results in permanent diabetes mellitus after delivery.
b) The onset of gestational diabetes typically manifests with hypoglycemia.
c) In some cases, women with gestational diabetes require insulin injections.
d) Diet and exercise are typically ineffective in controlling gestational diabetes.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1247			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
A pregnant trauma patient might lose a significant amount of blood before showing signs of shock because:

column3: a) pregnant patients can dramatically increase their heart rate.
b) pregnancy causes vasodilation and a lower blood pressure.
c) pregnant patients have an overall increase in blood volume.
d) blood is shunted to the uterus and fetus during major trauma.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Special Considerations for Trauma and Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1251			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Special Considerations for Trauma and Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 34-4 Discuss the need to consider two patients—the woman and the unborn fetus—when treating a pregnant trauma patient.
MC
If a pregnant patient must be placed onto a backboard, you should:

column3: a) place a folded towel behind her head to make it easier to breathe.
b) elevate the right side of the board with rolled towels or blankets.
c) raise the foot of the board 12 inches in order to maintain blood pressure.
d) elevate the head of the board six inches to prevent breathing impairment.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1258			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-6 Explain assessment of the pregnant patient.
MC
The presence of meconium in the amniotic fluid indicates:

column3: a) an expected finding in full-term infants.
b) that the baby’s airway might be obstructed.
c) that the fetus is at least four weeks premature.
d) that full newborn resuscitation will be needed.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1254			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 34-7 Explain the significance of meconium in the amniotic fluid.
MC
Which of the following questions is of least pertinence when determining whether a mother will deliver her baby within the next few minutes?

column3: a) “When are you due?”
b) “Is this your first baby?”
c) “Have you had a sonogram?”
d) “Do you feel the need to push?”

MC
Which of the following is an indication of imminent birth?

column3: a) Rupture of the amniotic sac
b) Crowning of the baby’s head
c) Irregular contractions lasting 10 minutes
d) Expulsion of the mucus plug from the vagina

MC

You are assessing a 25-year-old woman who is 39 weeks pregnant. She is experiencing regular contractions that are approximately three minutes apart and states that her amniotic sac broke two hours ago. After taking the standard precautions, you should:

column3: a) apply high-flow oxygen.
b) place her on her left side.
c) assess her for crowning.
d) transport her immediately.

MC
When preparing a pregnant patient for delivery, you should position her:

column3: a) in a supine position with her legs spread.
b) on her left side with the right leg elevated.
c) in a sitting position with her hips elevated 12 inches.
d) on a firm surface with her hips elevated two to four inches.

MC
During delivery, it is most important to position your partner at the mother’s head because:

column3: a) the mother might become nauseated and vomit.
b) the mother needs to be apprised of the situation.
c) she might need emotional support during the delivery.
d) mothers often need assisted ventilation during delivery.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1258			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
A precipitous labor and delivery is most common in women who:

column3: a) have gestational diabetes.
b) are younger than 30 years of age.
c) have delivered a baby before.
d) are pregnant for the first time.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1258			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
When determining the frequency of contractions, you should time the contractions from the:

column3: a) end of one to the start of the next.
b) start of one to the end of the next.
c) end of one to the end of the next.
d) start of one to the start of the next.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1259			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
When the mother is experiencing a contraction, you should instruct her to:

column3: a) hold her breath.
b) push for 30 seconds.
c) take quick short breaths.
d) rest and breathe deeply.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1259			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding suctioning of a newborn’s mouth and oropharynx is correct?

column3: a) Suctioning is indicated prior to cutting the cord if respiratory distress is present.
b) Suctioning should be performed on all newborns immediately following delivery.
c) Newborns rapidly expel fluid from their lungs and do not require suctioning.
d) If the head delivers face-down, the mouth and nose should be suctioned at once.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1266			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-15 Explain the steps to take in neonatal assessment and resuscitation.
MC
During your visual inspection of a 25-year-old woman in labor, you see the baby’s head crowning at the vaginal opening. What should you do?

column3: a) Apply gentle pressure to the baby’s head as it delivers.
b) Tell the mother not to push and transport her immediately.
c) Place your fingers in the vagina to assess for a nuchal cord.
d) Maintain firm pressure to the head until it completely delivers.

MC
Upon delivery of the baby’s head, you note that its face is encased in the unruptured amniotic sac. You should:

column3: a) give the mother high-flow oxygen and transport at once.
b) puncture the sac and suction the baby’s mouth and nose.
c) leave the amniotic sac intact until arrival at the hospital.
d) note the color of the amniotic fluid before breaking the sac.

MC
A nuchal cord is defined as an umbilical cord that:

column3: a) has separated from the placenta.
b) is wrapped around the baby’s neck.
c) is lacerated due to a traumatic delivery.
d) has abnormally developed blood vessels.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1263			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-12 Explain the necessary care of the fetus as the head appears.
MC
Upon delivery of an infant’s head, you note that the umbilical cord is wrapped around its neck. You should:

column3: a) immediately clamp and cut the umbilical cord.
b) give high-flow oxygen to the mother and transport.
c) provide free-flow oxygen to the infant and transport.
d) first attempt to slip the cord gently over the infant’s head.

MC
After a baby is born, it is important to:

column3: a) ensure that it is thoroughly dried and warmed.
b) position it so that its head is higher than its body.
c) cool the infant to stimulate effective breathing.
d) immediately clamp and cut the umbilical cord.

MC

Following delivery of a full-term baby, you have properly cared for the baby and have clamped and cut the umbilical cord. During transport, you note that the mother is experiencing moderate vaginal bleeding. You should:

column3: a) elevate her legs six to eight inches and cover her with a blanket.
b) firmly massage the uterine fundus with a circular motion.
c) carefully insert a sterile trauma dressing into her vagina.
d) place her legs together and position her on her left side.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1265			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
Which of the following is not generally considered an obstetrical emergency?

column3: a) Failure of the placenta to deliver after 30 minutes
b) Significant bleeding after delivery of the placenta
c) Return of contractions following delivery of the baby
d) More than 500 ml of blood loss before placental delivery

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Normal Delivery Management			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1265			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Normal Delivery Management			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-10 Explain the steps involved in normal delivery management.
MC
A newborn infant will usually begin breathing spontaneously within _______ seconds following birth.

column3: a) 3 to 5
b) 5 to 10

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Neonatal Assessment and Resuscitation			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1266			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Neonatal Assessment and Resuscitation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-15 Explain the steps to take in neonatal assessment and resuscitation.
MC
Common interventions used to stimulate spontaneous respirations in the newborn include all of the following, except:

column3: a) suctioning of the upper airway.
b) thorough drying with a towel.
c) positive-pressure ventilations.
d) some form of tactile stimulation.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Neonatal Assessment and Resuscitation			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1266			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Neonatal Assessment and Resuscitation			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 34-15 Explain the steps to take in neonatal assessment and resuscitation.
MC
If a newborn’s heart rate is less than 60 beats/min following delivery, you should:

column3: a) flick the soles of its feet.
b) begin chest compressions.
c) re-suction the mouth only.
d) provide ventilations for 30 seconds.

MC
In contrast to abruptio placenta, placenta previa:

column3: a) might not present with heavy vaginal bleeding.
b) might present without significant abdominal pain.
c) is caused by hypertension or abdominal trauma.
d) is typically associated with severe abdominal pain.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Complications of Pregnancy			Subject:Obstetrics and Neonatal Care, Page 1248			Title: Obstetrics and Neonatal Care			Feedback: See Complications of Pregnancy			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 34-3 Recognize complications of pregnancy including abuse, substance abuse, hypertensive disorders, bleeding, spontaneous abortion (miscarriage), and gestational diabetes.
MC
You have just delivered a premature baby. Your assessment reveals that he is breathing adequately; however, his heart rate is 90 beats/min. You should:

column3: a) keep him warm and ventilate with a bag-mask device.
b) begin chest compressions and reassess in 30 seconds.
c) clamp and cut the umbilical cord and keep him warm.
d) assess his skin color and give free-flow oxygen as needed.
postterm pregnancy, and fetal demise.

Which of the following is not a component of the Apgar score?

column3: a) Pulse
b) Activity
c) Grimace
d) Body size

If a baby is born at 7:52, the second Apgar score should be calculated at:

You have just delivered a baby boy. His body is pink, but his hands and feet are blue. His heart rate is approximately 110 beats/min, and his respirations are rapid and irregular. He has a weak cry when stimulated and resists attempts to straighten his legs. His Apgar score is:

MC
You have just delivered a full-term infant. His respirations are rapid and irregular, and he has a strong cry. What should you do next?

column3: a) Allow the mother to hold her baby.
b) Clamp and cut the umbilical cord.
c) Check the pulse rate at the brachial artery.
d) Begin assisting the newborn’s breathing.

Which of the following statements regarding a breech presentation is correct?

column3: a) A breech presentation occurs when the buttocks are the presenting part.
b) There is minimal risk of trauma to the infant with a breech presentation.
c) It is impossible to deliver a breech presentation in the prehospital setting.
d) Breech deliveries occur rapidly, so the EMT should deliver at the scene.

Your 22-year-old patient is in active labor. Upon visual inspection, you note that the infant’s leg is protruding from the vagina. Appropriate management of this situation includes:

column3: a) placing the mother supine with her head down and pelvis elevated.
b) gently pulling on the infant’s leg to facilitate delivery.
c) placing the mother in a recumbent position and rapidly transporting.
d) carefully attempting to push the infant’s leg off of the umbilical cord.

MC
The only indications for placing your gloved fingers in the vagina during delivery are:

column3: a) breech presentation and prolapsed umbilical cord.
b) limb presentation and severe vaginal hemorrhage.
c) vertex presentation and delivery of the placenta.
d) nuchal cord and presentation of an arm or leg.

MC
While examining a woman in labor, you see the umbilical cord protruding from the vagina. You should:

column3: a) carefully push the cord back into the vagina.
b) gently push the infant’s head away from the cord.
c) cover the umbilical cord with a dry dressing.
d) gently pull on the cord to facilitate delivery.

Spina bifida is a developmental defect in which:

column3: a) an excessive amount of cerebrospinal fluid damages the spinal cord.
b) nerve fibers that arise from the spinal cord do not function properly.
c) the spinal column is severely deformed, resulting in permanent paralysis.
d) a portion of the spinal cord or meninges protrudes outside of the vertebrae.

An abortion occurs when the fetus and placenta deliver before:

column3: a) 20 weeks.
b) 24 weeks.
c) 26 weeks.
d) 28 weeks.

Which of the following statements regarding twins is correct?

column3: a) Twins are typically larger than single infants.
b) Identical twins are typically of different gender.
c) Most twins are born within 45 minutes of each other.
d) Fraternal twins have two cords coming from one placenta.

Fetal complications associated with drug- or alcohol-addicted mothers include all of the following, except:

column3: a) low birth weight.
b) profound tachycardia.
c) premature delivery.
d) respiratory depression.

MC
An infant is premature if it:

column3: a) is born before 38 weeks’ gestation or weighs less than 6 pounds.
b) weighs less than 5.5 pounds or is born before 37 weeks’ gestation.
c) is born before 40 weeks’ gestation or weighs less than 7 pounds.
d) weighs less than 5 pounds or is born before 36 weeks’ gestation.

MC
In contrast to a full-term infant, a premature infant:

column3: a) has an even proportionately larger head.
b) is often covered with excess vernix material.
c) is one who is born before 38 weeks’ gestation.
d) retains heat better because of excess body hair.

After delivery of a pulseless and apneic infant who has a foul odor, skin sloughing, and diffuse blistering, you should:

column3: a) begin full resuscitation and transport.
b) report the case to the medical examiner.
c) provide emotional support to the mother.
d) dry the infant off to stimulate breathing.

Three days after delivering her baby, a 30-year-old woman complains of a sudden onset of difficulty breathing. Her level of consciousness is decreased, and she is tachycardic. The EMT should suspect:

column3: a) intrauterine bleeding.
b) pulmonary embolism.
c) acute pulmonary edema.
d) spontaneous pneumothorax.

CPR is in progress on a pulseless and apneic 29-year-old woman who is 37 weeks pregnant. When treating this patient, the EMT should:

column3: a) deliver a compression rate of 120 to 140 per minute.
b) manually displace the patient’s uterus to the left.
c) avoid defibrillation because it might harm the fetus.
d) perform compressions slightly lower on the sternum.

After delivery of the placenta, the mother is experiencing vaginal bleeding. After massaging the uterine fundus and allowing the mother to breastfeed, the bleeding stops. This occurred because:

column3: a) breastfeeding causes uterine blood vessels to dilate.
b) a portion of the placenta was retained in the uterus.
c) uterine massage increases blood flow to the uterus.
d) the production of oxytocin caused uterine contraction.
